section_01.section_summary: The chapter discusses the life and work of Sir Joshua Reynolds, a prominent English painter of the 18th century. Reynolds' talent, industry, and common sense enabled him to achieve great work, and his time in Italy, where he studied and copied the works of masters, was invaluable to his development as an artist. He was influenced by various artists, including Michelangelo, Titian, and Rubens, and was able to take the best from each and apply it to his own work. After returning to England, Reynolds quickly gained success as a portrait painter, thanks to the quality of his work and the patronage he received, and he went on to become the first President of the Royal Academy. His legacy as a great artist has endured, and his work continues to be celebrated for its mastery of technique and its ability to capture the essence of his subjects.

section_02.section_summary: Many artists are only interesting to talk to when discussing their own work, but some, like Sir Joshua Reynolds, are accomplished men of the world with broader interests. Reynolds was fortunate to have friendships with notable figures such as Dr. Johnson, Garrick, and Burke, which likely inspired and influenced him. Despite his intellectual curiosity, Reynolds had his flaws, including snobbery, jealousy, and vulgarity, which he partly overcame through his associations with refined people. However, these flaws sometimes led to lapses in taste, such as his ostentatious display of wealth. Overall, Reynolds' life and personality are more interesting and nuanced when considered in their entirety, rather than being idealized or sanitized.
